awd_titl_txt: Responding to Post-Hurricane Maria Needs for Electronics and Photonics Technicians in Puerto Rico
awd_abstract_narration:
The demand in Puerto Rico for highly-skilled technicians in the fiber-optics and photonic fields has increased following the collapse of all basic services following Hurricanes Irma and Maria in September 2018. STEM technicians in these fields are critical for the reconstruction and maintenance of the island's communication infrastructure.  This work includes rebuilding and modernizing the fiber-optic network that enables cell-phone and data transmission systems.  It also includes support of optical-based processing and quality control systems used in the manufacturing, medical devices, security, metrology, and pharmaceutical industries. This project proposes to meet local workforce needs by increasing the number of graduates earning an Associate Degree in Photonics and Lasers. Through a partnership with local industries, the current program will be expanded to align the curriculum with local needs and to focus more specifically on optics and photonics.  This focus will serve the most pressing local needs to support reconstruction and growth of the local optical fiber network.  Finally, this curriculum will provide an education that will allow graduates to pursue opportunities in the continental US.

The project will build upon the one-year certificate program that was previously developed under a Department of Labor TAACCCT grant.  Starting with this foundation, the project will identify, adopt, and adapt relevant educational materials from existing ATE-supported projects and Centers such as the National Center for Optics and Photonics Education and its affiliate centers and colleges. These materials will be re-oriented to meet local educational and community needs.  Existing industry relationships will be leveraged to better understand current local needs, and a Business and Industry Leadership Team will be developed to provide the project with expert advice. Outreach to high-schools will be expanded through a recruiting and outreach program and annual summer workshops for science and math high-school teachers. Project goals include offering a more flexible, industry-validated degree program with embedded certificate options and educating students who are proficient in optics, lasers, fiber optics, electronics, and control.  In addition, the project aims to ensure that students develop basic understandings of how business and entrepreneurial skills can be applied to the use of photonics and fiber optics in different industries. Proposed activities aim to excite high-school students and teachers about the power and applicability of light-based science and technology, and its current and potential impact on the local STEM economy. In addition, because the College serves many Hispanic students and women, the project has the potential to broaden participation of underrepresented groups in the technician workforce.  This project is funded by the NSF Advanced Technological Education program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Period of activity: 2019-07-15 -- 2021-06-30

This project, ?Responding to post-Hurricane Maria Industry Needs for Electronics and Photonics Technicians in Puerto Rico? was launched in July 2019 with the following objectives:

  • Strengthen our recruiting, outreach, and retention by familiarizing high school students to opportunities in photonics and optics
  • Strengthen our relationships with local industries through a Business-Industry Leadership Team (BILT)
  • Adapt our curriculum to the skillsets required by those industries
  • Establish a path from our 2-year associate to a 4-year engineering degree.

Relative to these objectives, we achieved the following:

  • Recruiting, outreach, and retention

With NSF support, we hired a marketing student to develop and carry out a recruiting plan. Though he resigned after about a month for personal reasons, we were able to conduct a number of recruiting activities. These included the following:

  • Multiple recruiting visits to two telecommunications companies
  • Public outreach at three shopping malls
  • Participation in multiple Open House recruiting events at two of our university campuses
  • Presentations at two high schools
  • We held a fiber optics workshop at our Engineering School.

Following the shutdown in March, we held a series of summer Facebook Live presentations (all in Spanish at https://facebook.com/prphotonics), which have 100s of views. These include the following:

  • May 16 International Day of Light presentation on fiber optic seismic sensors
  • May 24 Aerospace Applications of Photonics
  • May 31 Fiber Optics ? how do they work?
  • June 7 Fiber Optics Installer Certification
  • June 14 Associate Degree Program
  • June 21 Photonics and Energy
  • June 28 Photonics and Remote Sensing
  • July 12 Lasers in Manufacturing
  • July 19 Fiber Optics and Telecommunications
  • July 26 Photonics and Medicine.

On Nov. 24 and Dec. 17, we held two Facebook Live recruiting events with questions and answers.

In March 2021, we recorded an informational ?micro-capsule? for social media and TV.

  • Industry relationships and the BILT

We inaugurated the BILT and held remote meetings on 3/18/2020, 6/25/2020, 10/9/2020 and 11/5/2020.

We surveyed the BILT on the following:

  •  
    • Our proposed program name change to ?Associate Degree in Engineering for Lasers and Telecommunications Technologies?. (average score 4.0 of 5)
    • Whether representatives would volunteer at our recruiting activities (average score 3.6 of 5)
    • Whether our graduates who apply for jobs could be promised interviews, the responses were neutral.
    • We asked starting salary ranges, the responses were as follows:

BILT members urged the following action items:

  •  
    • Address trainings they currently carry out in the mainland US
    • Improve focus on quality of work
    • Acquire and train in 3-D lithographic printing. Two members offered to help prepare a budget supplement request to purchase the printer (not completed)
    • Students should participate in mock job interviews. (never realized)
    • Emphasize vision systems for inspection and quality control (already part of our curriculum)
    • Integrate basic knowledge of metallurgy for joining (welding) and characteristics of common metals
    • The Puerto Rico Manufacturers? Association agreed to carry a survey prepared by us (not completed).
  • Curriculum adaptation

Our Fiber Optics elective course, critical to adapting to industry needs, was approved by the University?s Academic Committee and Administrative Council. The program name change was approved by the university in fall 2020 and by the state regulatory agency in spring 2021. We modified the course sequence for regulatory compliance.

  • Articulation pathway from the 2-year AD to a 4-year BS in Engineering

In the first months of the project, we met with the Dean of Engineering. We held follow-up meetings with the Dean and Associate Dean of Science and Technology and then with the Associate Dean of Engineering. We analyzed our AAS program to align with the Bachelors programs in Electrical and Computer Engineering. We presented progress to the Dean of Engineering and later to the Dean of Science and Technology and University Chancellor. This work was interrupted by the pandemic.

We also participated ten meetings and conferences (eight virtual).

Broader Impacts

The project has allowed us to greatly improve a Continuing Education Fiber Optics Certification course that we offer.

Summary

We were not able to complete the goals and objectives of this project and ultimately determined that the most responsible course of action was to terminate the grant one year early. Challenges faced include:

  1. Inability to recruit effectively, exacerbated by:
    1. The loss of our student recruiter after one month
    2. Challenges to the university presented by the earthquakes, pandemic, and demographic changes
  2. Difficulties realizing industry commitments to recruiting, interviews, and programmatic activities
  3. The academic program was embargoed by the university.

We have recommended that the program be reconstituted in the Division of Engineering.
